headline.main: My Dinner With Clay Shirky, and What I Learned About Friendship

docs.abstract: You can follow someone on Twitter and friend them on Facebook, but real friends are people you break bread with.
docs.snippet: You can follow someone on Twitter and friend them on Facebook, but real friends are people you break bread with.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, I had dinner at Clay Shirky's house along with a group of journalists and academics, all of whom are very active on the Web. Mr. Shirky is the oft-quoted thinker who wrote "Here Comes Everybody" and "Cognitive Surplus." I have no idea why he was having the dinner or why I was invited, only that it sounded like a fun, smart bunch. We all "know" each other, either through a direct online connection or by digital reputation, but I am more familiar with them as digital avatars than as people.

headline.main: My Dinner With Clay Shirky, and What I Learned About Friendship

docs.lead_paragraph: Fructose consumption may increase cardiovascular risk factors because it increases visceral fat, the kind that accumulates around internal organs.

headline.seo: Fructose Consumption Increases Visceral Fat, Study Reports
headline.main: Risks: Fructose Intake Is Linked to Visceral Fat
headline.print_headline: Risks: Fructose Intake Is Linked to Visceral Fat

docs.abstract: Study by Norman K Pollock published in The Journal of Nutrition finds fructose consumption, largely from high-fructose corn syrup, may increase cardiovascular risk factors because it increases visceral fat, the type that accumulates around internal organs.
docs.snippet: Fructose consumption may increase cardiovascular risk factors because it increases visceral fat, the kind that accumulates around internal organs.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a low-protein diet, the body is forced to get its protein from lean body mass, a study shows.

headline.seo: Low-Protein Diets May Be Costly to Lean Body Mass
headline.main: Nutrition: Low-Protein Diet May Cost Lean Body Mass
headline.print_headline: Nutrition: Low-Protein Diet May Cost Lean Body Mass

docs.abstract: Dr George A Bray study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association finds that people consuming excess calories on a low-protein diet may gain less weight than others, but they will also lose lean body mass.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Janet Holwell first joined Weight Watchers seven years ago, she lost 43 pounds in one year and considered the popular commercial weight-loss plan ''miraculous.'' ''I felt like I had found the magic key, the secret that eluded me all of these years,'' said Ms. Holwell, who has maintained most of her weight loss by continuing to adhere to the program.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I want to get in touch with my inner healthy person (we've been estranged since mid-December), I do an organic cold-pressed juice fast or a juice/raw food combination cleanse from Marcus Antebi's excellent Juice Press. Until now, he's had few rivals for my affections. But Jamie Graber, a pretty redhead who used to work at Live Live (one of the best spots in town for supplements and packaged raw foods), is giving him a bit of friendly competition with Gingersnap's Organic, her new East Village cafe. Graber offers a few cold-pressed juices, but her main focus is "handcrafted conscious cuisine," or raw, vegan, gluten-free food. Any of you who eat raw know how delicious - or disastrous - this kind of (non) cooking can be. But Graber and her chef have created a menu full of yummy, creatively seasoned offerings, like zucchini almond hummus, carrot-coconut dal and portobello Reuben wraps. Forget those ubiquitous flax seed crackers. At Gingersnap's, the crisps are a little more exotic, with flavors like zaatar, vadouvan and chipotle.

docs.lead_paragraph: The city health department’s campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of their bad habits has drawn some criticism for its negative approach.

headline.seo: Some Say New York City Health Ads Should Inspire, Not Scare
headline.main: New York City Defends Health Ads That Frighten the Viewer
headline.print_headline: City Defends Health Ads That Frighten the Viewer

docs.abstract: New York City's health department defends its use of health ads that use graphic images and scenarios to frighten the target audience, tactic that is part of the Bloomberg administration's relentless campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of bad health habits; says use of what has been criticized as a negative approach, is merely stating the hard, cold realities and scientific evidence.
docs.snippet: The city health department’s campaign to jolt New Yorkers out of their bad habits has drawn some criticism for its negative approach.
